Comment: This was an interesting game that had me extremely pressured and on the defence despite being a whole piece ahead. White begins the game with the Bird's Opening
nothing special so far...Black has slightly better control of the centre, while White could have an opportunity for a future kingside attack - nothing decisive so far
nothing special so far...Black has slightly better control of the centre, while White could have an opportunity for a future kingside attack - nothing decisive so far

pinning the knight...
but that is easily averted. I now look at queenside castling
?! I'm not sure what the point of this move is, especially since it blocks the c3 square for White's knight. 5.d4 or 5.Nc3 would have been better alternatives
attempting to force the bishop away....
but White would like the bishop to stay. The defending knight, however, isn't going to be as safe as it would like to be....
the start of a pawn chain, and a chance to get up a piece. Will White see it?
nope - White instead advances his other knight. Better would have been to retreat the bishop to stop Black's next move...
! the threat here is 8...Bxa3 9.bxa3 Qxb5, with the added bonus of doubled pawns on the a file. White sees this and tries to stop the threat....
and it should have been enough to stop Black getting a material advantage...
? were it not for this move. White should have played Bxd7 first, and now Black wins a piece...
? were it not for this move. White should have played Bxd7 first, and now Black wins a piece...
like this. Now it should just be a simple matter of trading down material to have an endgame advantage for Black
like this. Now it should just be a simple matter of trading down material to have an endgame advantage for Black
like this. Now it should just be a simple matter of trading down material to have an endgame advantage for Black
chasing my queen away....
and the queen makes sure that White doesn't get any more attacks on her
White's a and b pawns could turn out to be pretty dangerous....
so maybe castling wasn't the best option here. Better would have been 12...a6
now White chooses to shut off the queenside. I'm not worried - all my pieces are on the kingside.
hoping to provoke an en passant capture, to allow my pieces some breathing room (e.g 14.exf5 e.p Nxf6 with Bd6 next move)
White will have none of it!
